adrs.title: Use Event Sourcing technique to store the state of the application
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We have to be able to send app state change in a form of events. It would be nice also to give app creator the view into the history & audit of app changes. In the same time the app guests should not contain such a history. How to achieve that?

## Decision Drivers

- Well know architectural pattern
- Flexible to use


## Considered Options

- Event Sourcing

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Event Sourcing", because in deciders current knowledge there is no better option for this requirement. The app creator will be able to keep track of all events in the form of proposed by Event Sourcing pattern. The app creator will be able to audit the app, send the app changes since specified timestamp or even revert app to the specified point in time. The app guest will only get a snapshot of the current app without any more knowledge.

adrs.title: Use json_dynamic_widget to render applications
adrs.verbatim:
- Deciders: Crisperit
= Tags: apps

## Context and Problem Statement

Flutter does not have the ability to render apps from JSON as well as to perform any Hot Updates. That means that we cannot keep any apps in the core build and also that we need some Flutter solution for defining the apps in a for of JSON.

## Decision Drivers

- Flexible
- Actively maintained
- Open for extensions
- Allowing for creating dynamically changed actions


## Considered Options

- [json_dynamic_widget](https://pub.dev/packages/json_dynamic_widget)
- [dynamic_widget](https://pub.dev/packages/dynamic_widget)

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "json_dynamic_widget", because of the ability to define custom values & functions. The ability to subscribe for value stream as well as the overall possibilities of that library makes it a perfect fit for our needs. We also are contributing to that project because their growth is in our best interest.

## Pros and Cons of the Options

### json_dynamic_widget

- Good, because it has flexible custom values & functions model
- Good, because it is actively maintained
- Good, because it allows to define dynamic actions like add, remove, edit via [json_dynamic_builder](https://github.com/peiffer-innovations/json_dynamic_widget/blob/main/lib/src/builders/json_dynamic_builder.dart)
- Good, because we are contributing there
- Bad, because there is no possibility to convert Flutter Widgets to JSON, they have to be manually written

### dynamic_widget

- Good, because has the ability to convert Flutter Widgets to JSON
- Bad, because it is not open to extensions and their functionality is limited rather to just showing views and data

## Links

- Relates to <AdrLink slug="20220129-store-applications-in-a-form-of-json" status="accepted" title="Store applications in a form of JSON" customLabel="Store applications in a form of JSON" />

adrs.title: Use JWT standard for users communication
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

The users will communicate with each other via shared cloud folders like Google Drive / Dropbox. Even if the link to that shared account will be passed only between two users - we have to ensure security even in case of stealing that link. How we can securely pass JSON events?

## Decision Drivers

- Payload size
- Security
- Library support

## Considered Options

- Signed and encrypted JWT as described in [here](https://connect2id.com/products/nimbus-jose-jwt/examples/signed-and-encrypted-jwt)

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Signed and encrypted JWT as described", because it provides the best known security level. The JSON event is firstly signed (JWS) and then encrypted (JWE) and provides the best security level. We can think also about giving a choice for disabling the encryption part. Some users might want to prefer performance over security and we can give them a choice.

## Links

- Relates to <AdrLink slug="20220130-make-user-communicate-via-their-shared-cloud-folders" status="superseded" title="Make user communicate via their shared cloud folders" customLabel="Make user communicate via their shared cloud folders" />

adrs.title: Use single form snake case for package names
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We have to decide one convention for packages / folders naming to achieve more uniformly structured project. 

## Decision Drivers

- Easy to read
- Recommended by other Dart/Flutter devs

## Considered Options

- Snake case single form
- Snake case multiple form

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Snake case single form", because snake case is recommended by Dart in [here](https://dart-lang.github.io/linter/lints/package_names.html). Single form like `asset` will be better than `assets` because the single form is shorter and used by default in a generated project (lib, ios, test, web).

## Links

- https://groups.google.com/a/dartlang.org/g/misc/c/llBY5-oCk9o

adrs.title: Use Flutter as cross-platform framework
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We want to make our app as a multi-platform solution and we cannot afford to maintain multiple of code bases. What would be the best option to consider for this project?

## Decision Drivers

- Do not take too many time for platform customizations
- Performance
- Easy to develop
- Support for creating views from the JSON

## Considered Options

- Flutter
- React Native

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Flutter", because of its ability to look almost the same on every platform and the overall near native performance. The Dart language is also giving a lot of possibilities to create really clean code. React Native deciding disadvantage was the need to make a lot of platform customizations.

### Positive Consequences
- Beautiful apps that looks the same one every platform

### Negative Consequences

- Flutter does not have any way to load views/widgets from JSON - we have to find a library which supports that
- We have to put a lot of effort in the testing the app because we cannot deliver fixes via Hot Update features

## Pros and Cons of the Options

### Flutter

- Good, because Google is really caring about that project and there is also a plan to use it as a native language in upcoming FuchsiaOS
- Good, because it does not depend on native components and looks everywhere the same
- Good, because of Hot Reload & Hot Restart feature
- Good, because Dart language is giving a lot possibilities to write clean code
- Good, because of having a lot of actively developed packages
- Good, because of active community
- Bad, because it requires new language to learn
- Bad, because there is no Hot Update feature
- Bad, because it does not support natively loading views/widgets from the JSON
- Bad, because of the slightly bigger build size

### React Native

- Good, because it only requires JS knowledge
- Good, because React Components can be created from the JSON
- Good, because of Hot Update feature
- Good, because of Hot Reload & Hot Restart feature
- Good, because of active community
- Bad, because of depending on native platform components. In some cases apps possibilities will have to be reduced because of that and additionally the apps might looks differently
- Bad, because of the worse performance

## Links

- https://doit.software/blog/flutter-vs-react-native#screen22

adrs.title: Use Log4brains to manage the ADRs
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We want to record architectural decisions made in this project.
Which tool(s) should we use to manage these records?

## Considered Options

- [Log4brains](https://github.com/thomvaill/log4brains): architecture knowledge base (command-line + static site generator)
- [ADR Tools](https://github.com/npryce/adr-tools): command-line to create ADRs
- [ADR Tools Python](https://bitbucket.org/tinkerer_/adr-tools-python/src/master/): command-line to create ADRs
- [adr-viewer](https://github.com/mrwilson/adr-viewer): static site generator
- [adr-log](https://adr.github.io/adr-log/): command-line to create a TOC of ADRs

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Log4brains", because it includes the features of all the other tools, and even more.

adrs.title: Use Markdown Architectural Decision Records
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We want to record architectural decisions made in this project.
Which format and structure should these records follow?

## Considered Options

- [MADR](https://adr.github.io/madr/) 2.1.2 with Log4brains patch
- [MADR](https://adr.github.io/madr/) 2.1.2  The original Markdown Architectural Decision Records
- [Michael Nygard's template](http://thinkrelevance.com/blog/2011/11/15/documenting-architecture-decisions)  The first incarnation of the term "ADR"
- [Sustainable Architectural Decisions](https://www.infoq.com/articles/sustainable-architectural-design-decisions)  The Y-Statements
- Other templates listed at <https://github.com/joelparkerhenderson/architecture_decision_record>
- Formless  No conventions for file format and structure

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "MADR 2.1.2 with Log4brains patch", because

- Implicit assumptions should be made explicit.
  Design documentation is important to enable people understanding the decisions later on.
  See also [A rational design process: How and why to fake it](https://doi.org/10.1109/TSE.1986.6312940).
- The MADR format is lean and fits our development style.
- The MADR structure is comprehensible and facilitates usage & maintenance.
- The MADR project is vivid.
- Version 2.1.2 is the latest one available when starting to document ADRs.
- The Log4brains patch adds more features, like tags.

The "Log4brains patch" performs the following modifications to the original template:

- Change the ADR filenames format (`NNN-adr-name` becomes `YYYYMMDD-adr-name`), to avoid conflicts during Git merges.
- Add a `draft` status, to enable collaborative writing.
- Add a `Tags` field.

## Links

- Relates to <AdrLink slug="20220128-use-log4brains-to-manage-the-adrs" status="accepted" title="Use Log4brains to manage the ADRs" customLabel="Use Log4brains to manage the ADRs" />

adrs.title: Store applications in a form of JSON
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

The key requirement of this project is to make users able to download possibly infinite amount of apps. The conclusion from that is that we have to keep applications outside of the prappser_app. In what format should the applications be stored? 

## Decision Drivers

- Easy to use
- Well-known
- Supported by widget parsing libraries

## Considered Options

- JSON
- YAML
- Hot loaded dart modules

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "JSON", because it has better serialization & deserialization performance than YAML. It is also better supported by the available for 

## Pros and Cons of the Options

### JSON

- Good, because easy to read
- Good, because good serialization & deserialization performance
- Good, because supported by available Widget parse libraries

### YAML

- Good, because easiest to read
- Bad, because lack of direct support by Widget parse libraries

### Hot loaded dart modules

- Good, because it would not require any parser layer
- Bad, because it is not possible ... yet?

adrs.title: Use PlantUML to create most of diagrams
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

In the docs we want to sometimes create the diagram (e.g. use case diagram). We need some easy to use, in code solution for that. What should we choose?
## Decision Drivers <!-- optional -->

- In file and text diagram
- Easy to use
- Easy to maintain

## Considered Options

- PlantUML
- Draw.io

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "PlantUML", because it allows to draw complicated diagrams with a bunch of text lines. It is easier to maintain text diagram cause we do not have to manually draw and move arrows etc. It is easier to maintain the same style across multiple of diagrams. It is also easier to solve any conflicting diagram changes. We should use "PlantUML" whenever we can and use "Draw.io" only when we cannot draw something in "PlantUML".

## Pros and Cons of the Options

### PlantUML

- Good, because can be kept in text file
- Good, because easy to use syntax
- Good, because easy to perform change to the diagram
- Good, because easy to solve conflicts
- Bad, because less flexible than graphical solution

### Draw.io

- Good, because can be kept as a XML file
- Good, because intuitive UI
- Good, because of wide amount of possibilities
- Bad, because hard to solve conflicts in the diagram
- Bad, because time consuming to make the changes
- Bad, because hard to ensure the same style across multiple of diagrams

adrs.title: Keep linear git history via squash restriction
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

The amount of commits can grow over time. One single PR can contains multiple of commits due to PR fixes. The commit mess can grow over time. In case of a need to revert one single feature it is much easier to revert single commit instead od ten of them. We have to ensure that we keep linear git history.

## Decision Drivers

- Easy to setup
- Automatic - so that devs do not have to remember about it

## Considered Options

- Squash restriction on PRs

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Squash restriction on PRs", because it is easy to setup and it makes near impossible for PR creators to merge multiple requests to the main branch. Squash commit message prompt is also a good opportunity to set more clear commit message by a merger.

## Links

- https://www.bitsnbites.eu/a-tidy-linear-git-history/

adrs.title: Make user communicate via their shared cloud folders
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

The most important part of the Prappser is the user communication. Users will send through the internet app state changes, app join requests etc. in a form of JSON events.  We do not want to be able to track our users in any way. We also want to be able to scale to million of users without being impacted by big costs. We want to totally free way of communication because we do not want to make the Prappser paid solution - but OpenSource. Is that even possible? 
## Decision Drivers

- Totally free
- Secure
- Scalable to infinite numbers
- Untraceable us in any way

## Considered Options

- Public MQTT servers
- Shared Cloud folders
- Localhost connection + dynamic Hamachi room creation

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Shared Cloud folders", because it is most scalable and available to any user solution. It is also pretty secure and it allows users to be in a total control over their data (even send one data). We also want to add the possibility in a future for things like backups or user devices sync.

### Positive Consequences

- We can scale to the near infinite numbers without paying a $
- Total control over data in the hand of users
- We can integrate with a lot of Cloud Services

### Negative Consequences

- We have to ensure that shared folders links do not expire
- Such kind of communication might be slow so we have to put a lot of effort to simplify communication protocol

## Pros and Cons of the Options

### Public MQTT servers

MQTT protocol is perfect for the case of that application. It is message broker optimized for IoT. It allows to create infinite amount of topics.
There are a few of hosted brokers available for free. 

- Good, because MQTT protocol is fitted for our case
- Bad, because MQTT public servers are limited
- Bad, because we cannot be so sure if they will be enabled all the time
- Bad, because they scale poorly (the instance hosted in one region and nothing more)
- Bad, because we cannot send big files

### Shared Cloud folders

Each user nowadays have some kind of Cloud Storage account (Google Drive/Dropbox/Mega/OneDrive...). And rather all of these solutions allows to share the folders by publicly available link.
One user can then connect with other user by creating a shared folder. If two users will create a shared folder for themselves then there is possible a file based communication. Each shared folder can contain subfolders which can be used like topics in message brokers.

- Good, because scalable. Every Cloud Storage service like Google Drive/Dropbox has their servers scattered over the world
- Good, because totally free
- Good, because users can remove whole folder with all data that Prappser have
- Good, because the data is stored on users accounts which are secured by Cloud Storage services
- Good, because we cannot track our users
- Bad, because such a shared cloud folders mutual listening communication might be slow

### Localhost connection + dynamic Hamachi room creation

We can add the possibility to allow users to connect only to the users in the same net. In case of desire to connect with someone outside of the local net then we can provide some kind of integration with [Hamachi](https://www.vpn.net/) service.

- Good, the communication protocol will be simple
- Good, because we can send big files
- Bad, because we require users to create Hamachi account if they want to connect with each other

adrs.title: Use conventional commits standard for commit messages
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We need some well known commit standard to keep our git history clean, informative and consistent. What standard should we use?

## Decision Drivers

- Well-known
- Easy to use

## Considered Options

- [Conventional Commits](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/en/v1.0.0/)

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Conventional Commits", because it is well-supported and well-known standard. It also works pretty well with GitHub releases thanks to GitHub Actions like [conventional-changelog-action](https://github.com/TriPSs/conventional-changelog-action).

adrs.title: Use Github Action to build CI / CD
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

Every project needs solid CI / CD pipelines. What tool should we use for them?
## Decision Drivers

- No additional costs
- Easy to use

## Considered Options

- GitHub Action
- Jenkins

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "GitHub Action", because it meets with all criteria. We do not plan to change GitHub on something else for now - so the only cons is not affecting us at all.

## Pros and Cons of the Options

### GitHub Action

- Good, because free to use (with some limitations)
- Good, because really easy to setup
- Good, because there is a lot of community plugins
- Bad, because we are more tied to GitHub

### Jenkins

- Good, because there is a lot of community plugins
- Good, because we do not have to rewrite all pipelines in case of changing Git provider.
- Bad, because it requires additional infrastructure costs

adrs.title: Download apps directly from prappser_site repository
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

Applications will be kept in a form of JSONs and rendered in the prappser_app via json_dynamic_widget library. where these apps should be kept?

## Decision Drivers

- Low cost of storage
- No limits for daily downloads

## Considered Options

- Downloading from prappser.com
- Downloading directly from prappser_site repository

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Downloading directly from prappser_site repository", because it is totally free, unlimited and tied to the prappser_site repository which can be used for apps active development.

## Pros and Cons of the Options

### Downloading from prappser.com

- Good, it does not require a lot of effort and can be easily achieved
- Bad, because we can hit a limit
- Bad, because if we hit the limit then it will cost us $

### Downloading directly from prappser_site repository

GitHub has the possibility to download raw public files via https://raw.githubusercontent.com/

- Good, because unlimited
- Good, because free
- Good, because people can actively develop the apps on that repository

## Links

- Relates to <AdrLink slug="20220129-use-jsondynamicwidget-to-render-applications" status="accepted" title="Use json_dynamic_widget to render applications" customLabel="Use json_dynamic_widget to render applications" />
- Relates to <AdrLink slug="20220129-store-applications-in-a-form-of-json" status="accepted" title="Store applications in a form of JSON" customLabel="Store applications in a form of JSON" />

adrs.title: Separate app state management layer from communication layer
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We are struggling to find the best approach for user communication. Previously chosen at <AdrLink slug="20220130-make-user-communicate-via-their-shared-cloud-folders" status="superseded" title="Make user communicate via their shared cloud folders" /> seems to be best in most of the cases, but we are worried about performance of such a method. Direct connection would be better than the one based on files listening. What should we do?

## Decision Drivers

- Flexibility
- Free

## Considered Options

- Separate app state management layer from communication layer

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Separate app state management layer from communication layer", because it will give us possibility to propose multiple of communication methods to our users. We will be able to propose:
- Shared cloud folders connection
- LAN connection
- Server connection
- and other ideas...

We do not have to find the best for all cases communication method. We can just be able to propose multiple of solutions and let users find the best. It will be all possible thanks to code separation.

### Positive Consequences
- Users will be responsible for finding the best communication methods to their apps

## Links

- Supersedes <AdrLink slug="20220130-make-user-communicate-via-their-shared-cloud-folders" status="superseded" title="Make user communicate via their shared cloud folders" />

adrs.title: Use Riverpod architecture
adrs.verbatim:
## Context and Problem Statement

We are about to start developing the prappser app aand... we have to agree on the architecture of the app. 
How to make state management? How to separate view from domain?

## Decision Drivers

- Separation of concerns
- Testability
- Pretty easy to understand

## Considered Options

- Riverpod architecture from codewithandrea.com

## Decision Outcome

Chosen option: "Riverpod architecture from codewithandrea.com"
